title: Browserify dependency needs cloneWithProps
body:
Hi, recently I've upgraded my project from React 0.14 to 15, and as you might know, on this last version 'cloneWithProps' is deprecated and you must use 'cloneElement' instead. Well, browserify install 'module-deps' as a dependency, and this one installs 'browser-resolve', which installs 'resolve' and this one needs 'react-addons-clone-with-props'. Is there a way to fix this with a new version of `browserify`, or how should I approach this?

This is the output of my gulp build:

`Error: Cannot find module 'react/lib/cloneWithProps' from '/home/ppmiron/Development/Project/node_modules/react-addons-clone-with-props'
    at /home/ppmiron/Development/Project/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-resolve/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:46:17
    at process (/home/ppmiron/Development/Project/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-resolve/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:173:43)
    at ondir (/home/ppmiron/Development/Project/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-resolve/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:188:17)
    at load (/home/ppmiron/Development/Project/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-resolve/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:69:43)
    at onex (/home/ppmiron/Development/Project/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-resolve/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:92:31)
    at /home/ppmiron/Development/Project/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-resolve/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:22:47
    at FSReqWrap.oncomplete (fs.js:82:15)
`

title: Replace `acorn` parser for `babylon`?
body:
Hi.

I have created fork of `browserify` which uses `babylon` parser instead of `acorn`.

This change allows targeting transpilation into Babel's compatible code.

More info here: https://github.com/substack/node-detective/issues/71

I can create PR for all updated packages if there is interest:

https://github.com/zdychacek/node-browserify
https://github.com/zdychacek/node-syntax-error
https://github.com/zdychacek/node-detective
https://github.com/zdychacek/module-deps
https://github.com/zdychacek/lexical-scope
https://github.com/zdychacek/insert-module-globals
https://github.com/zdychacek/astw

Cheers,

O.

body:
I am trying to compile a large program into a single file.

I am using `Node 8.0.0`.

`browserify --node index.js > out.js`

This command works if I don't use `async` and `await`.

How can one make it work? Node 8 supports async/await out of the box and if I do `node index.js`, it just works.

Thanks!

title: Browserify always prefers .js and .json over custom extensions
body:
When building my project, I use browserify with coffeeify and I set `extensions: ['.coffee']` in configuration. I also have automatic coffeescript compiler running in my IDE to quickly see how the compiled code for a file looks. I don't use extensions in my `require` calls.

Problem is, when compiling, browserify prefers the already compiled `.js` files over the source `.coffee` files, which breaks the generated source map (it maps to the `.js` files instead of the real source).

In `index.js` of browserify on line 433, extensions are added in the following way:
`mopts.extensions = [ '.js', '.json' ].concat(mopts.extensions || []);`

I suggest reversing the operation and appending `.js` and `.json` to the end, so it gives precedence to custom extensions.

title: When "main" matches source and "browser" field set, bundle fails.
body:
Using browserify 14.4.0. masOS Sierra.

Quite a weird repro. When running this command:
```bash
browserify module.js -o dist/module.js
```
And under this set of circumstances:
* The `"main"` field in package.json matches the source file (`"module.js"`)
* The `"browser"` field is also set (with any value, but in our case `"dist/module.js"`)

We get this error when bundling:
```bash
Error: module not found: "/<pathroot>/module/module.js" from file /<pathroot>/module/_fake.js
```

Changing the `"main"` field to something else allows browserify to succeed. Removing the `"browser"` field also works. Of course these aren't options for distribution.

title: Cannot bundle when it includes an already bundled module
body:
In package A I am bundling with latest browserify + babelify library code written in ES6 into its `/dist/a.js` file whichi is also defined in the `main` entry of its package.json. And it's published like that to npm along with its source code in the `/src` folder.

Now, in another project B, I am requiring that package A in the app code and browserify all together before running the app B. And here it fails, it cannot resolve some dependencies A is having.

Makes me wonder if it's good practice to browserify another bundle which already has been browserified?

(on a side note, it does not happen when `main` in package.json is pointing to the source code entry instead of the dist file. So that confirms it's a bundling issue.)

title: Add support for the Node v6 preserve-symlinks option
body: When specified, symlinks are preserved when resolving modules. Specifically, the `realpath` call is skipped. This allows symlinked peer dependencies to work correctly. Matches the behavior of the option added in node v6.3.0: https://nodejs.org/api/cli.html#cli_preserve_symlinks. See https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/3402 for discussion around this feature in node.

I often see this code on the beginning of "exported" node apps:
    
    (function(f){if(typeof exports==="object"&&typeof module!=="undefined"){module.exports=f()}else if(typeof define==="function"&&define.amd){define([],f)}else{var g;if(typeof window!=="undefined"){g=window}else if(typeof global!=="undefined"){g=global}else if(typeof self!=="undefined"){g=self}else{g=this}g.Foo = ...

But if I use Browserify to made an export manually, like shown below, this part is missing. I do it like this:

Could somebody tell where this code (long line in the first block) came from? From Node or from Browserify? And how to set up Node (or, respectively, Browserify) to "get" this code on export.

title: crypto no longer works
body:
It looks like something broke crypto with changes pushed today. Did not investigate where the change came from so I am reporting it here.

To reproduce:

```javascript
var crypto = require('crypto')
```

This will produce the following error:

```
index.js:3 Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'toString' of undefined
    at Object.require.270.crypto (index.js:3)
    at s (_prelude.js:1)
    at _prelude.js:1
    at Object.require.164.browserify-cipher (index.js:12)
    at s (_prelude.js:1)
    at _prelude.js:1
    at Object.require.1.../../src/example (index.js:7)
    at s (_prelude.js:1)
    at e (_prelude.js:1)
    at _prelude.js:1
```

where:

```javascript
crypto.pbkdf2Sync.toString()
```

will is called on undefined object, i.e. crypto.pbkdf2Sync is not defined.

Again, this regression is relatively new. Perhaps due to a change from today.

title: browserify production/development/staging/testing/etc... flags to change the set of applied transforms
body:
This pull request enabled the usage from the cli. 
https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/pull/1709

I just figured out, that when I use:
* `browserify --transform-key=production index.js > bundle.js`

Then browserify will also use that `production` key for all the dependencies.
Most dependencies, if they have a `"browserify"` field in `package.json` only specify `"transform"` property and not a `"production"` property, so browserify often fails when the custom `--transform-key` feature is used.

**How to deal with this?**
* Would it be "smart" to automatically fall back to the "transform" key if for example in the above example a "production" key is specified?

body:
Hello,

I have reproduced the bug in this repo
https://github.com/ErikLarsson82/browserify_alias_bug/tree/browserify_only

Using grunt, there is an alias option and from its docs it says
> It's equivalent to require: [ ['./foo.js', {expose: 'foo'} ] ]

In the repo, I instead use this syntax using browserify without grunt:
`browserify app.js -o bundle.js -r react-dom:alias-test -s foo`

I interpret this code as "take react-dom and expose it as alias-test"
Inside the app code, i can indeed `require("alias-test")`

Now, in my entry point I do
`module.exports = "123"`
... but using the alias option the module instead exports react-dom object.

title: TypeError: browserify(...).transform(...).on(...).pipe is not a function
Using require() API can cause process to hang
body:
When creating a bundle through the Node API should you provide `require` with a path that will not resolve the error event will be invoked put the process will not end.

Should you `require()` in that exact same invalid path in a module, not using the `browserify().require()` API the exact same error event will but thrown, but this time the process will end.

I would have expected in both scenarios the error to be fired but then the process to end?

So if i have an `input.js` of:
```javascript
'use strict'

require('myModule');
```
And run this 
```javascript
browserify()
    .add('./input.js')
    .require('./some/invalid/path', {
        expose: 'myModule'
    })
    .bundle()
    .on('error', (e) => {
        // Fires
    });
```
it will error but the node process will never end.

However if i remove the `require()` call and instead have this in my `index.js` it will also error but the process wont hang.
```javascript
'use strict'

require('./some/invalid/path');
```

I've worked around it by manually asserting that the path exists before giving it to Browserify, However that isn't entirely ideal in the long run.

I can reproduce this on the latest `14.1.0` version.

title: browserify field flags to switch behavior based on dev/prod/...
body:
Browserify has the awesome feature, that every dependency can specify it's own transforms in a "browserify" field in it's `package.json` :+1: 

**My issue:**
* While I'm developing I run watchify and don't need minification or extensive testing or transpilation of modern es6 code and beyond and I want my pipelin to be fast.
* When I'm building for production, I want minification and transpilation es6toes5 for legacy browser support and a separate source maps file and so on...

**Idea:**
Is it or would it be possible to switch the behavior of a module's "browserify pipeline" as defined in it's "browserify field" based on environment variables or alternatively based on spec?

**I would be willing to try to come up with an implementation and a pull request - but i first want to make sure if this would be acceptable and if so - what would be the best way** :-)

title: Question: "Process" object becomes a browser process instead of a node process
Exclude option not working using Gulp
Top level options for external/exclude/ignore
body:
Is there any technical reason not to expose `external`/`exclude`/`ignore` options in `Browserify` constructor the same way it has been [done for `require`](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/fe8c57b86c586a3625257871e370fc6f278d1df5/index.js#L95-L97)? Looks a bit inconsistent with CLI.

It would be very convenient to have single "options object" that represents a bundle. E.g.

```js
    var bundleConfig = {
            entries: 'src/index.js',
            ignore: 'jquery',
            external: ['./vendor'],
            debug: true,
            transform: [
                    ['babelify'],
                    ['exposify', { react }]
            ]
    };
```
and then, for example `budo({ browserify: bundleConfig})` while developing and `browserify(bundleConfig)` in production. It's exactly my use case however I easily could imagine many others

title: Define overrides in programmatic API?
body: How?

title: Alternative for "browser" key with higher priority
body:
I've stumbled upon this issue in https://github.com/mwilliamson/mammoth.js/pull/106

`browser` key is widely used for defining which file should be used in browser environment. Some tools might use this field optionally, but they also have an alternative which is tool-specific, for instance, [in webpack](https://webpack.github.io/docs/configuration.html#resolve-packagemains).

Could you add support for something like `browserify.browser` with higher priority in addition to `browser`?

title: --no-browser-field breaks transforms
body:
Using `aliasify` transform alongside with `--no-browser-field` results in output like following:
```
node_modules/.bin/browserify lib/index.js --standalone mammoth --no-browser-field --transform aliasify -p browserify-prepend-licenses > mammoth.browser.js
Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, lstat '/***/mammoth.js/path'
makefile:12: recipe for target 'mammoth.browser.js' failed
make: *** [mammoth.browser.js] Error 1
```

Here is the commit where I'm switching from using `browser` key in `package.json` to `aliasify`: https://github.com/nazar-pc/mammoth.js/commit/d2e0cf48fa8416b8a60518d1796334e69aa42249

If you just remove `--no-browser-field` key it works, but doesn't make sense, since `browser` key is already useless for Browserify.

title: Tree-shaking and destructured require optimizations
body:
It'd be great if:
```js
const {normalize:normalizePath} = require('path');
```
…and perhaps also:
```js
var normalizePath = require('path').normalize;
```
…would behave like:
```js
import {normalize as normalizePath} from 'path';
```
…in that it would only bundle `normalize()` and anything required for it to run.

title: Version upgrade of module-deps
body:
Recently [module-deps@4.1.0](https://github.com/substack/module-deps/releases/tag/4.1.0) was published with a new cache API. This PR updates the dependency and enables it for browserify 😍. 

_General side question:_
_Wouldn't it be better to change the dependency of `module-deps` and `browser-pack` to a `>4.1.0` and `>6.0.0` since we are respecting the semver and pass all configuration to the packages anyways:_

> All other options are forwarded along to module-deps and browser-pack directly.

title: Fix interaction between fullPaths and external
body:
Consider the case where you are splitting bundles with your own code, not in node_modules. You have bundle 1, which has the `require` calls, and you also have bundle 2, which makes the same `external` calls. Assume the default expose names and relative require arguments with no aliasing magic.

When `fullPaths` is false in both, this works fine if you are careful with setting `basedir`. When `fullPaths` is true in both, bundle 1 will expose absolute paths but bundle 2's external IDs are the ones relative to the basedir. As #1534 notes, currently you can't get bundle 2 to look for the absolute paths, so if you want to use an ecosystem tool requiring `fullPaths`, you're stuck.

(The potential workaround of specifying `expose` yourself may run into #1629, though I didn't check carefully. For that issue, I think the suggested fix works, i.e. patch deps-sort in the obvious way, but that's separate from this PR.)

This PR makes it so that if you compile bundle 2 with `fullPaths` true, the external IDs are absolute paths. So `fullPaths` is now usable. One minor disadvantage: consistent `fullPaths` settings across bundles is now a requirement. If someone has it where bundle 1 is compiled with `fullPaths` false and bundle 2 is compiled with `fullPaths` true, their setup works now and my PR will break it.

title: path.resolve requires strings
body:
This relates to https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/1029 which is closed so I'm opening this ticket
.
I'm running

npm 4.1.2
Gulp
  CLI version 1.2.2
  Local version 3.9.1
guplfile.js is attached (my first use of gulp so I've used examples from various places)
[gulpfile.txt](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/files/772291/gulpfile.txt)
Fedora 24

I'm using this (https://github.com/gulpjs/gulp/blob/master/docs/recipes/handling-the-delete-event-on-watch.md) as a reference and have

  var filePathFromSrc = pathfunc.relative(pathfunc.resolve(paths.html.src, event.path));

where paths.html.src and event.path are variables containing paths.

I get back the path.resolve requires strings message but I find it hard to believe that is really true.  How can someone write a function that only accepts strings and ignore reusability considerations and the fact that variables would be passed to it..

Has it been fixed - as far as i can tell it's not fixed so any workarounds to get a relative path other than roll my own ?

Note the .toString() does not work.

Is this fixed in gulp 4?  I assume gulp 4 is still alpha or beta?

Thanks.

title: Unneeded dependencies pulled in for dependencies with`browser` property
body:
[public-ip](https://github.com/sindresorhus/public-ip) has a `browser` property in package.json which points to [browser.js](https://github.com/sindresorhus/public-ip/blob/master/browser.js), which currently only includes the `is-ip` dependency. browserifying that give a lightweight package:

````sh
$ browserify browser.js | wc -c
    3355
````

But if one creates another project that depends on the `public-ip` package, the `got` dependency which is not actually used in `browser.js` (only in `index.js`) is needlessly included:

```sh
$ browserify my-project.js | wc -c
  287709
```

title: Prevent files from being required programatically
body:
I am using browserify like this:

```javascript
  var b = browserify();
  b.require('/path/to/app/root.js', {basedir: __dirname, expose: '__app'});
```
...etc.

I'm trying to make sure browserify doesn't bundle in certain `.js` files which are supposed to live on the server side, and should never make their way onto the client. To do so, I've tried to pass them in as `opts` to `browserify(opts)` with the following keys: `exclude`, `ignore`, `noParse`. 

For example:

```javascript
var b = browserify({
  noParse: ['path/of/file/to/never/include/in/bundle.js']
});
```
All to no avail.

Is there any way to do this?


*Extra context which might or might not be useful:*
These `.js` files which I'd like to ignore should never accidentally make their way into the client bundle, even if unwittingly required. I don't care what happens instead, I just don't want the modules to silently sneak in. It's fine if a blank object, for example, was imported instead.

title: bundler.require() overrides inner requires
body:
issue is reproduced here: https://github.com/kovalenko0/reproduce-browserify-replacements

## Steps to reproduce
```
git clone https://github.com/kovalenko0/reproduce-browserify-replacements.git
cd reproduce-browserify-replacements
npm i
node build
node project/bundle.js
```

## Actual result
logs `using outer module` to console
which means that instead of 
`project/node_modules/my-module/node_modules/another_module/index.js`
is used
`project/node_modules/another_module/index.js`

## Expected result
`project/node_modules/my-module/node_modules/another_module/index.js` is used for
`project/node_modules/my-module` and `using inner module` is logged to console


## Additional notes
If you remove following code from `build.js` it works as expected:

```
bundler.require(path.resolve('./project/node_modules/another_module'), {
  expose: 'another_module'
})
```

title: util.inspect options maxArrayLength, breakLength
body:
Does anyone know a better shim for util.inspect? I spent a few hours testing lots of modules from npm, but can't find any that supports options maxArrayLength and breakLength.
Is there any hope to [fix the util module currently used by browserify](https://github.com/defunctzombie/node-util/issues/15)?

title: Allow user-specified ignore stub
body:
If an ignored `require()` exports a function, then you get the following error:
`Uncaught TypeError: require(...) is not a function`

I noticed this with chart.js:
https://github.com/chartjs/Chart.js/blob/master/src/chart.js

The requires export a function that modifies the `Chart` object.

If these requires are ignored, then it replaces them with the standard `1:[function(require,module,exports){},{}]` without removing the `(Chart)` after the require statement.

Perhaps allowing the user to specify the "stub" function would be a good solution?

E.g.
```javascript
browserify(input)
  .stub("module.exports = function(x){};")
```

Just to add, I'm currently using the following workaround.
It depends on the stub being function `1`.
```javascript
browserify(input)
    .ignore('require')
    .bundle()
    .pipe(source('file.js'))
    .pipe(replace(/1:\[function\(require,module,exports\){\s+},{}\],/,
      '1:\[function\(require,module,exports\){module.exports=function\(x\){};},{}\],'))
    .pipe(gulp.dest(out_dir));
```

title: Can't seem to ignore requires that start with '.'
release tags now contain a "v"
body: browserify as of v14.0.0 now contains a prefix, Is this intentional as citgm will need to update their lookup to include the prefix

title: latest release include 'v' prefix in release tag
body: All previous releases did not include the `v` prefix in the tag, `v14.0.0` is the first and breaks the pattern of no prefix e.g. `13.3.0`.

title: Update 'buffer' to v5.x
body:
### Browser support

buffer v5.x drops support for IE8-10.

This allows us to remove the `Object` implementation and rely on a single
fast implementation based on Typed Arrays, greatly simplifying the maintanence of the
buffer package.

Typed arrays are supported by 97.08% of the U.S. browser market and 92.02% of the
global browser market. Source: http://caniuse.com/#search=typed This number 
continues to increase at a steady rate each month.

If IE8-10 support is critical to your web app, you can continue to rely on
browserify v13.

### Bundle size

This change shrinks the size of buffer modestly.

55.1kb -> 52.1kb (full size, with comments)
7.0kb -> 6.7kb (minified, gzipped)

### Bug fixes

buffer v5.x contains several important fixes including:

- https://github.com/feross/buffer/commit/3639a98a97888477d1bc6b335fb27b48b550a751
- https://github.com/feross/buffer/commit/4e5c4526f4c29201fa833a89d8fe2bf15ebb18e5
- https://github.com/feross/buffer/commit/99491d2f16d6f20940dd86ed2cb6e8629181723e

### Semver

This should be released as semver major.

I came into this problem when I try to split up bundles.

First, I  create a bundle named `moduleA`:
`browserify -r ./moudule-a.js:moduleA -o ./bundle/module-a.js`

Then I create another bundle which requires `moduleA` inside:
`browserify -x ./bundle/module-a.js -r ./module-b:moduleB -o ./bundle/module-b.js`

And I got this error: 
`Cannot find module 'moduleA'`

I don't know where I did wrong. Any help?

title: Unable to alias local module with npm name in "browser" field
Write to temp outfile until success, fixes #899
body:
Write browserify command output to a temporary file, overwriting the target file atomically upon success (and simply cleaning up the tempfile on error).

This has two benefits:

* user won't be left with an empty file if compilation fails (which can break toolchains that rely on destination files/timestamps to indicate build status, Make or django-pipeline for just two examples) i.e. fixes #899 
* output file can never end up in a half-written state during even a successful compilation

title: Updated and complete version of the zlib shim
body:
There is a new version of the `browserify-zlib` shim to zlib available at https://github.com/ipfs/browserify-zlib, it fixes some bugs and more importantly, it adds support for dictionaries.

It seems that not a lot of people use that feature, but it is essential for `libp2p-spdy` in the browser, which is part of `js-libp2p` and `js-ipfs`. Right now we are replacing the shim in our build tool, but it would improve the experience a lot if everyone using it could just the shim that gets injected by browserify.

We've a open PR -- https://github.com/devongovett/browserify-zlib/pull/18 -- to the bundled `browserify-zlib` in browserify, but 8 months have passed since it was open, the author and maintainer seems to be lacking the time to review. What else an we do to move this forward?

Thank you :)

//cc @dignifiedquire @VictorBjelkholm

title: Update copyright year in LICENSE
Allow configuring transformKey option for module-deps
body: module-deps supports specifiying the transformKey to use for looking up the transforms defined in package.json of dependencies. In some cases it is desirable to suppress this behaviour. This PR allows you to specifiy this via browserify options.

I've submitted pull requests to upgrade the acorn version used by all the node-browserify dependencies I could find.

* substack/astw#10
* substack/browser-unpack#15
* substack/node-detective#67
* substack/node-syntax-error#18

`npm test` passes in all repos. Let me know if I missed one and I'm happy to submit another PR.

title: Can't exclude/ignore/external a peerDependency
body:
Any peer dependency of a package cannot be excluded when requiring that package.

e.g. Using package [react-select](https://www.npmjs.com/package/react-select), which has a [peer dependency on react](https://github.com/JedWatson/react-select/blob/v1.0.0-rc.1/package.json#L44), the following command will always include react in the bundle, despite the fact that it has been excluded with `-u`. `-i` and `-x` behave the same.
```
browserify -r react-select -u react -o bundle.js
```

This was tested with version 13.1.1 of Browserify. You can find an example using Gulp with the Browserify API in [browserify-exclude-test](https://github.com/codebling/browserify-exclude-test).

body:
Hi, I’m trying to use the library [mysql](https://www.npmjs.com/package/mysql) on a client in combination with Cordova.

In the library is the 'net' required and so inserted (var Net = require('net');), so shouldn’t browserify insert that one as well in the bundle.js, that the function is available?

title: Library to be exported to commonjs/nodejs but not to AMD (so no --standalone flag)
body:
Hello,

We have a library that uses browserify to be exported into a one single bundle file that must be executed in different environments. A priori the typical UMD pattern seemed cool but it does not fit with all our library requirements. Basically, our library does not support to be executed in pure AMD environments and the reason is that we want to avoid the *lazy module initialization*. However, the typical UMD pattern allows that _lazy initialization_ when detecting that we are running within an AMD environment.

The reason behind disliking the _lazy module initialization_ is that we still want to support certain codes that like to be merged (our library + more stuff that depends on the previous code) and be run within an AMD environment. In that situation, when the 'other stuff' is executed then our code was expected to be already executed, but it wasn't yet, making it to fail.

I know that browserify has a flag *--standalone VAR* however I want to avoid it since it exports using the UMD pattern.

My conclusion is that the best is that browserify only exports to browser and commonjs/nodejs instead of to a proper UMD. The AMD support will be manually added to the code. Hence here are my questions:

* Is it possible to use a flag in browserify to only export a bundle as browser and commonjs/nodejs but not to AMD? (what does that *--node* flag do?).
* Otherwise, is there any plugin or way to change the export pattern so I can use my personalized one (a modified UMD)?

Thank you very much for your time.
